comments.commentBody: Assuming the position that the Egyptian Revolution is "Bush's Victory" requires believing the logical fallacy that President Bush's agenda in Iraq and the wider Middle East was actually a program for the promotion of electoral democracy. The reality, however, was quite the opposite- anyone with a handling of reality knows that the Bush Administration's policies in the Middle East, and in particular the decision to invade Iraq, were not the Fourteen Points risen from the dead, but  cold-hearted realpolitik designed to strengthen the United States' position in the region (for whatever real motive, be it oil, or some other strategic aim, of which we will sadly never know for sure). This is not to say that the U.S. Middle East policy during the Bush years was either good or bad, misguided Wilsonianism/security reality or evil oil executives, but let's not pretend for one second that what Bush spoke of was the White House's actual policy. More importantly, let's not pretend that this revolution is anything less than  the inevitable flourishing of freedom and liberty that is bound to occur in any oppressed state. This is Egypt's moment- the people, finally free of their fear beaten into them by the Mubarak regime, taking what is rightful theirs; their country.

Democracy requires, at minimum, an educated electorate. To the extent that we don't have one in the U.S., our own little experiment is failing. For instance, we would not have the right-wing nincompoops we have in the Congress if we had an educated populace. We would not have Supreme Court Justices who think corporations are people. We would not have perverted & contorted our electoral system into a special interest group bonanza. We would not have 10 percent of the population deciding who sits in the Senate.

Democracies also have a lot better chance of success if the populace is nominally secular. To the extent our own electorate is prejudiced & tainted by religious doctrines which the religious majority imposes upon the rest of us, our democracy is a failure. We would not have Jim Inhofe, all but one of the freshman Republican senators & a slew of dimwitted House members denying manmade climate change were it not for the prominence of religious fundamentalism.

In short, if Egyptians can create democratic institutions and hold free and fair elections, they have as good a chance as the U.S. does of making a "success" of a government by, for and of the people.

Good luck, Egypt!

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

Wait, you start this by quoting Elliott Abrams, who was hip-deep in the Reagan administration's Iran-Contra deal? You know the one, where we sold arms to the Iranians (our stated enemies) and to take the proceeds and fund the contras in Nicaragua, with the stated aim of replacing one undemocratic regime with another, but one 'friendlier' to our 'interests.' Sorry, Abrams wouldn't recognize democracy if it kneed him in the groin.

And then on you go to Charles Krauthammer, who has four points in his 'freedom agenda.' Every one of his caveats quickly and cleanly disqualifies our seemingly endless efforts in both Iraq and Afghanistan. Free elections? Free press? How's all that working out after a decade (in Afghanistan, whose government could not continue in power without our propping) and eight years in Iraq?

The only way that Bush's approach in Afghanistan and in Iraq even vaguely resembles what has happened in Egypt and in Tunisia is that the final effect has been regime change. And, in Egypt, Mubarak is only put out because the military has staged a coup. A military coup? In Egypt? Who could have seen that coming? In 1952, King Farouk was deposed in a military coup led by General Gamel Abdel Nasser. After the disastrous six day war, Nasser was cashiered and replaced by General Anwar El Sadat. After Sadat was assassinated by reactionaries furious about Sadat's attempt to make peace with Israel, Air Force General Hosni Mubarak took power. It is entirely unclear whether the military can be replaced by a democracy. Please read Nick Kristof's work. Could we be seeing a case of, as Pete Townshend put it: "Meet the new boss, same as the old boss."

Yeah, Bush 'accomplished' in a decade or in eight years what the Tunisian and Egyptian people facilitated in weeks, without the expenditure of a trillion dollars and without the loss of thousands of American lives, and without permanently disabling over 100000 Americans. In the words of Archie Bunker: "Whoop-de-damn-do."
By invading Iraq, George W. Bush lost all credibility as someone striving for freedom without violence.

There is a distinct difference between a Western country invading and occupying a country to impose so-called "freedom" on it (and killing all who got in the way) and the people themselves taking to the streets to take their country back.

I've been contemplating what might be happening in Iraq now, had we not invaded in 2003, but kept to a strict arms inspection regime, while pushing for openness and respect for human rights.

What we've witnessed in Tunisia and Egypt has been the power of nonviolent movements to topple governments. That's not to say the transitions will be free from violence, but in contrast the U.S. invasion of Iraq led to the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people--and the displacement of millions.

And these nonviolent movements didn't cost our treasury a dime.

Those seem to all be lessons George Bush never figured out, and Barack Obama may only be just beginning to learn.

Churchill?!  Churchill wanted to preserve after WWII British colonialism--perhaps the least democratic of all institutions--and only agreed to the principle of self-determination (i.e., give up the Empire) because he was forced to do so by Roosevelt.

Democracy is everybody's right regardless of their background. We are all human beings with similar aspirations and hopes. We all want freedom and dignity.
Tunisians and Egyptians got rid of their dictators. Now they need to create their own democracy.
As much as I am happy and hopeful, I am worried because it's only a beginning and it is still very fragile. Like a newborn who needs lots of support and help. I hope that the world will have the courage to accept this transition towards democracy and provide an unconditional support that will help both countries to achieve their dream.
It is very important that both countries start their democracy by rewriting a new constitution that won't give power to a single man. I am worried that this is not possible under the present conditions, especially in Tunisia where only a new president can dissolve the parliament and order a rewrite of a new constitution and it becomes the question of whose first the chicken or the egg.
Lets all hope and pray that the Arab world will succeed in this challenging endeavor. Their success is the beginning of the road to peace and prosperity in the region.

NOT surprised abdul jabbar has done this. he was one of the few TRUE so called student athletes who really was a student athlete. it is very unusual for an elite athlete of any colour to do something truly significant intellectually outside of playing their sport well.

indian PM has the candor (or he is senile) to admit that his cabinet does not listen to him. His finance minister says it is not his job to control inflation. Agriculture minister says not his job to increase food production. And they all still have their jobs.

Indians are not good at organizing or cooperation - the meaning of society. they are good at "solo artist" programming kind of work.

Agriculture techniques in India was never designed for the Urban Lifestyle. There are a multitude of factors which has led to this situation. The first is the farm holding structure. After Independence the Political class in order to show empowerment distributed land holding to individual farmers. The population when this activity started was around 300 Million ( 1950-60).  While the number of landholding went up, there was no action to industrialize the farms. In order to survive the farmers started to have more kids to work in farms. This vicious cycle still runs in most non industrialized states within India. The only way forward is to drive mechanization of farms and drive for larger cooperative farm holdings. Unfortunately the Political Class does not have the will to do the same..

I really admire the true-consensus that NYTimes makes on very remote issues like the one about the farmer in this article.
My father is a farmer living in a small village in Andhra Pradesh, India.My dad has striven hard to send me to a school and provide good education so that i wouldn't have to work hard in the fields like him. And now I am in IIT, the prestigious institute.And I am going to get a big pay-check after my graduation (it's not a big deal for IITian :P).
The point is, my dad has recently sold out the 5-acre farming land, as each year we are not able to even recover the money we put in the farming.There are many farmers like my dad with a good educated child, who are moving out of villages leaving the land.(Vastly i think this is the main reason behind increasing urbanization of India, well even the urban areas won't be able to sustain the increasing population)
There are so many other issues the article hasn't covered( of course, i don't expect such a large problems in agriculture system of India to be listed out in this tiny article). There is no modernization of agriculture, not at all, except for the one who has more acres of land and who can spend some money on the machine. My mom also started going to field as we are not able to recover the costs for machine and labor.And we have never stored out rice-grains in warehouses since 20 years i knew, it was always our own house.
There is an intense need to attract the youth to areas like these in India. There is lot of entrepreneurial-wind breezing in the India universities and there are lot of capable technological centers in India to modernize the agriculture.
At last, no individual, in gross, is driven by the dream to make India shine in world platform. Its his own belly he is trying to fill.So,I think if agriculture can be shown as a profitable modern-entrepreneurial venture, the elite of Indian students will be attracted.
Hope, one day, I will again grow crops in my sold-out land.

When Sheryl Gay Stolberg charges Robert Fisk with being inaccurate (the charge turning on Stolberg's and Patton Boggs's legalistic dodge), will she or the Times editors or its so-called "Public Editor" apply that same standard to any of the paper's notoriously inaccurate writers? Thomas Friedman, Judith Miller (in the many years when she was lying with Times editorial approval), Michael Gordon, Matt Bai, John Burns, David Brooks, Ross Douthat -- all with _repeated_ and _noted_ falsehoods. All writers whose work has been challenged accurately and thoroughly, yet who the Times holds near and dear.

Hatch voted for TARP because it was essential and he'd do it again but he's sorry he did it? Duh? To such have Republican members of the world's greatest deliberative body been reduced. The last gasp of gutlessness.
What a dour bunch of sourpusses!  I bet nobody ever gives you a gag gift.
Are we that stupid to forget how necessary the TARP was?
